content: The Act titled "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" introduces a new section, 25B, in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide a credit for health insurance costs of previously uninsured individuals. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001 introduces a new section, 25B, in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide a credit for health insurance costs of previously uninsured individuals. The credit allows individuals to claim an amount paid for coverage for themselves, their spouse, and dependents under qualified health insurance, with limitations on the maximum monthly amount. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001 introduces section 25B in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, providing a credit for health insurance costs of previously uninsured individuals. The credit allows individuals to claim amounts paid for coverage for themselves, their spouse, and dependents under qualified health insurance, with a monthly limitation of $1,500 per individual. No more than 2 individuals can be considered for the credit, with a special rule for married individuals who do not file a joint return. The special rule for married individuals under section 25B of the Internal Revenue Code states that only the individual who is married but does not file a joint return and does not live apart from their spouse throughout the taxable year can be considered for the credit. An eligible coverage month is defined as a month where the individual is covered by qualified health insurance. The subsection defines an "eligible coverage month" as a month where an individual is covered by qualified health insurance paid by the taxpayer and meets specific criteria regarding insurance coverage and employer-provided plans. There is also a limitation based on adjusted gross income. The subsection outlines criteria for an "eligible coverage month" related to health insurance and employer-provided plans. There is also a limitation on the tax credit based on adjusted gross income. The subsection defines criteria for an "eligible coverage month" for health insurance and employer-provided plans, with a limitation on the tax credit based on adjusted gross income. The amount determined under this paragraph is based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, which is calculated by increasing adjusted gross income by any excluded amounts under specific sections. The paragraph defines modified adjusted gross income as adjusted gross income plus certain exclusions. It also specifies rounding rules and applicable dollar amounts based on the taxpayer's health insurance coverage. The paragraph outlines dollar amounts for taxpayers with qualified health insurance coverage, based on marital status and number of individuals covered. Qualified health insurance is defined as insurance covering medical care, excluding certain benefits. The term 'qualified health insurance' is defined as insurance covering medical care, excluding certain benefits and coverage where less than 50 percent of the cost is borne by the taxpayer. No credit is allowed for amounts paid under specific government-provided programs. No credit is allowed for amounts paid under specific government-provided programs such as title XVIII, XIX, or XXI of the Social Security Act, chapter 55 of title 10, United States Code, chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code, or the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. Coverage under these programs is considered as coverage under qualified health insurance for eligibility purposes. Coverage under certain government-provided programs is considered as coverage under qualified health insurance for eligibility purposes. Special rules apply, including coordination with other deductions and denial of credit to dependents. Inflation adjustment for tax credits begins after 2002, with dollar amounts adjusted annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year. The dollar amount for tax credits is adjusted annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year. If the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $100, it will be rounded down to the nearest multiple of $100. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. Part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section on costs of qualified health insurance. In general, individuals can deduct the amount paid for qualified health insurance for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. Special rules apply, such as not double counting the deduction with other medical expenses and not using it for self-employment tax purposes. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. The deduction for qualified health insurance costs is not allowed for self-employment tax purposes. Amendments include adding the deduction to section 62 of the tax code and updating the table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1. The deduction for qualified health insurance costs is added to section 62 of the tax code and applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
